RR.advice: Calling or 4-betting if either of your opponents are on the loose side is fine with QQ in a 3-bet pot. However, calling and allowing the initial raiser to make a bigger mistake is preferred with a hand that won't have a large equity advantage if all the money goes in pre-flop.

R.advice: Against some opponents that are loose openers, re-raising AQs is ok as well.

O.advice: In some tougher games folding KQs UTG is best, otherwise open raise.

R.advice: Typically you should fold KQs in early position to a raise because you will be dominated by about 30-35% of your opponents UTG opening range. The rest of their range you will be flipping against, and depending on how loose they are, a slight dog.

RC.advice: If the opening raiser is loose, squeezing with AQo is ok, OR if the caller is a weak opponent you may be able to squeeze out the original opening raiser by 3-betting, and get the hand heads up against the weak opponent.

O.advice: In some very aggressive games you can fold this hand from early position.

R.advice: You will typically be dominated if you call with this hand from most early position raisers. Combine that with the fact you may face a raise from behind and have to fold, it's usually best to fold this hand.

Bet.Hand: A9s | A8s | A7s | A6s | A5s | A4s | A3s | A2s | QJs | JTo

O.advice: This hand is a bit too weak in today's games to be open raising from early position.
In full ring games UTG, this hand doesn't play well out of position if someone calls you. Unless your table is very weak tight, it's usually best to fold.

R.advice: Your hand is going to typically be in bad shape against an early position raise. It's best to fold unless you have a good read on your opponent.

O.advice: In more passive games, opening small pairs is ok. If the game you're in is aggressive, you should look to fold this hand.

R.advice: Assuming the raise you're facing is 10% of the effective stack sizes in play, this should be a call.

RC.advice: Assuming the raise you're facing is 10% of the effective stack sizes in play, this should be a call.

O.advice: Opening suited connectors in most full ring games typically isn't profitable. If your game is extremely weak tight, then you could consider opening a suited connector, but in general it's best to fold them.

R.advice: Against some opponents that are loose openers, re-raising AQs is ok. Calling and using your position is also ok.

RC.advice: It's typically best to call against an early position raiser and caller with AQs. If the opening raiser is really loose, you can look to squeeze, but it's usually best to call and use your position on both players.

R.advice: Against some opponents that are fairly tight, folding with KQs in middle position is ideal. Against weaker opponents, or opponents who open wider, calling is also ok.

L.advice: Raise and isolate the loose limper so you can give yourself multiple ways to win the pot is usually the best play. If your table is aggressive, then look to fold.

R.advice: This hand isn't strong enough to play against an early position raiser without a very good read.

RC.advice: This hand doesn't play well to a raise and a call unless effective stacks are fairly deep (over 130bbs or more).

L.advice: Raising and isolating the limper is a reasonable play, unless you have very aggressive opponents behind you. If so, then you should look to fold.

R.advice: If opponents behind you don't 3-bet a lot, then calling and playing this hand to hit a big drawing hand can be a good play. If you're unsure about your opponents though, it's usually best to fold and avoid either a 3-bet from behind you, or playing the hand sandwiched with opponents in front and behind you.
Unless your opponent is a loose opening raiser, then it's usually best to fold AJ to a raise when in middle position.

Bet.Hand: A9s | A8s | A7s | A6s | A5s | A4s | A3s | A2s | QTs | QJo | JTo

R.advice: Best to avoid potential domination and fold this hand to a raise in front of you. Against very loose or weak opponents, you can look to sometimes call.

L.advice: Sometimes in late middle position when the table isn't aggressive behind you can limp this hand.

R.advice: Off suited connectors in middle position don't play well against an early position raise. It's usually best to fold this hand unless stacks are deep and your opponents behind you aren't very aggressive.

L.advice: Raising and isolating the limper(s) in position is typically the best play so that you'll have initiative post flop and give yourself more than one way to win the hand.

Bet.Hand: A9s | A8s | A7s | A6s | A5s | A4s | A3s | A2s
AT | KTs | J9s | QTs | QT | QJ | JT

RC.advice: This hand doesn't play well to a raise and a call unless effective stacks are fairly deep (over 130bbs or more).

L.advice: If opponent behind you aren't aggressive you can sometimes look to limp behind here. Otherwise you're best to raise and isolate the limper(s) in position.

R.advice: Against looser opponents re-raising with JJ on the button is usually the best play, but against most reasonable opponents, calling and using your position is ideal.
Call and use your position with this hand. You can play for over card and set value.
Call with these hands when the raise is 5% or less if you or your opponent stack. When it's between 5 - 10% call only when your opponent isn't very good.

RC.advice: Call with these hands when the raise is 5% or less if you or your opponent stack. When it's between 5 - 10% call only when your opponent isn't very good.

R.advice: Facing a raise with AQ on the button it's usually best to call if your opponent is on the tighter side, and re-raise if your opponent is fairly looser and use your position.
With AJs on the button, it's usually best to call and see a flop. Re-raising against very loose raisers can be fine as well, but usually calling is best.

RC.advice: AJs can play decent in a multi-way raised pot when you're in position. It's usually best to call, but sometimes squeezing can also be ok.

Bet.Hand: ATs | A9s | A8s | A7s | A6s | A5s | A4s | A3s | A2s

L.advice: Raising and isolating your opponent is a profitable play with this hand. If you have weak opponents in the blinds, it's also sometimes good to limp to allow them into the hand as well.

R.advice: Without initiative in the hand, these are difficult to play profitably, even in position. Unless your opponent is very weak, fold this hand.

RC.advice: When there's a raise and a call, only call with a suited ace in position if one of your opponents is very weak, or stacks are fairly deep.

L.advice: Look to take the initiative by raising, and isolate loose limpers with these hands.

R.advice: Playing weak off suited aces to a raise, even in position typically isn't profitable. It's best to fold these hands unless you feel you have a very good read on your opponent.

L.advice: Look to take the initiative by raising, and isolate loose limpers with AJ.

R.advice: Fold if your opponent is fairly tight, otherwise call and use your position post flop.

RC.advice: With a raise and a call, AJ doesn't play that well, even in position. If your opponents are extremely weak, then you can sometimes look to call, but it's usually best to fold and avoid domination.

Bet.Hand: KTs | KJs | KQs | QJs | QTs | KJ | KQ

L.advice: With limpers in the pot, this is a good hand to raise and either win without seeing a flop, or building a pot in position against an opponent with a likely weaker hand.

R.advice: Call when your opponents are weak, and fold when they are stronger players.

RC.advice: Call when your opponents are weak, and fold when they are stronger players.

L.advice: With limpers in the pot, this is a good hand to raise and either win without seeing a flop, or building a pot in position against an opponent with a likely weaker hand.

R.advice: It's usually best to fold this hand to a raise unless your opponent is extremely weak.

RC.advice: With a raise and a call, it's usually best to not play this hand. Sometimes calling with it's suited version on the button is ok.

R.advice: The weaker you read that your opponent is, the more you should lean towards a call. If your opponent is pretty strong, you can look to fold this hand.

L.advice: Raising and isolating the players in front of you is a +EV play, as well as limping behind if the blinds are weak and keep a larger stack to pot ratio post flop.

R.advice: It's usually best to fold this hand, even in position. If your effective stacks get over 130bbs, then calling with this hand in position is perfectly fine.

Bet.Hand: K8s | K9s | A7 | A6 | A5 | A4

L.advice: If the opponents in the blinds are weak, it's usually best to limp behind and keep even more weak opponents in the pot with you. Raising to isolate your opponents is also a reasonable play if the players in the blinds are competent opponents.

R.advice: Calling raises with off suited connectors will require you to make bluffs post flop in order to make the hand profitable. If you're comfortable with bluffing a good amount of the time, then you can sometimes call with these hands. Otherwise you're better off folding, especially when stacks are close to 100bbs deep.

L.advice: Limp behind if your opponents in the blinds are weak, and you can keep them in the pot. Otherwise raise and take the initiative in the hand.

R.advice: Against tight early position raisers, calling is ok with JJ. Against loose openers, re-raising and taking the initiative is ideal.

RC.advice: Against tight early position raisers, calling is ok with JJ. Against loose openers, squeezing and taking the initiative is ideal.

R.advice: Sometimes re-raising TT, especially against late position raisers is ideal. Otherwise call against most raisers.
Call and play this hand primarily for set value post flop.

L.advice: Typically best to limp since you'll be out of position, and with limpers in, you'll need to bloat the pot to get the hand heads up.

R.advice: Call with these hands when the raise is 5% or less if you or your opponent stack. When it's between 5 - 10% call only when your opponent isn't very good.

RC.advice: Call with these hands when the raise is 5% or less if you or your opponent stack. When it's between 5 - 10% call only when your opponent isn't very good.

R.advice: Re-raise sometimes against late position raisers with AJs, otherwise call.

RC.advice: Squeezing is fine with this hand if you don't feel confident with your post flop game. Otherwise call.

Bet.Hand: A9s | A8s | A7s | A6s | A5s | A4s | A3s | A2s

R.advice: This hand doesn't play well profitably from out of position to a raise.

L.advice: If opponents are showing weakness, and there's no raises yet, then you should look to raise and either take down the pot or take the initiative in the hand.

R.advice: This hand doesn't play well profitably from out of position to a raise.

L.advice: Raise to take the initiative against your opponents range that is typically weaker than your hand.

R.advice: If you feel confident with your post flop game, calling is reasonable. Otherwise look to fold this hand being out of position.

RC.advice: If you feel confident with your post flop game, calling is reasonable. Otherwise look to fold this hand being out of position.

L.advice: If your opponents are fairly aggressive post flop, then calling is ok. Otherwise look to raise and take control of the hand post flop.

R.advice: This hand doesn't play well profitably from out of position to a raise.

RC.advice: Sometimes multi-way this hand can play ok, but be careful post flop. Othewise fold this hand out of position.

L.advice: Calling or raising are both reasonable plays in a limped pot.

R.advice: Playing this hand out of position to a raise is unprofitable, unless your opponents are weak post flop.

RC.advice: Sometimes multi-way this hand can play ok, but be careful post flop. Otherwise fold this hand out of position.
Sometimes multi-way this hand can play ok, but be careful post flop. Otherwise fold this hand out of position.

L.advice: Usually in a limped pot this hand can be fine to play in a limped pot. It's ok to fold them as well, and wait for a slightly stronger hand.

R.advice: Re-raise against loose open raisers with TT, otherwise call and play the hand for set and over card value.
Call with these hands when the raise is 5% or less if you or your opponent stack. When it's between 5 - 10% call only when your opponent isn't very good.

RC.advice: Call with these hands when the raise is 5% or less if you or your opponent stack. When it's between 5 - 10% call only when your opponent isn't very good.

R.advice: Re-raising with AQ is fine, especially against later position openers, and players that are loose in general. However, calling and concealing your hand strength a bit is also fine.

RC.advice: If you're going to re-raise with AQ after a raise and a call, you have to look to get it in pre-flop, unless you're very deep. Usually just calling is best, but sometimes squeezing, and eliminating the issue of post flop position is also fine.

R.advice: Usually best to call with AJs and see a flop.

Bet.Hand: ATs | A9s | A8s | A7s | A6s | A5s | A4s | A3s | A2s

R.advice: Typically not best to call with weaker suited aces out of position.

RC.advice: Typically not best to call with weaker suited aces out of position.

L.advice: It's best to raise and take the initiative against the loose limpers, even though you're out of position.

R.advice: Playing this hand from out of position against a raise is difficult to do profitably. Sometimes calling with AJ should be the bottom range that you can call with a read.

RC.advice: Playing this hand from out of position against a raise and a call is difficult. It's best to fold unless you have good reads on your opponents.

Bet.Hand: KJs | KQs | QJs | QTs | JTs | KQ

L.advice: When the pot is limped, it's usually best to raise and take the initiative in the hand, even when you're out of position.

R.advice: Call if your opponents aren't that great, or fold if they play well post flop.

RC.advice: Call if your opponents aren't that great, or fold if they play well post flop.

Bet.Hand: KTs | J9s | KT | KJ | JT | QJ

R.advice: With a raise in front of you, playing this hand out of position is typically not profitable.

RC.advice: With a raise and a call in front of you, playing this hand out of position is typically not profitable.

R.advice: It's generally not good to play small suited connectors to a raise out of position unless you feel you have a very good read on your opponent, or your opponent is very weak.

RC.advice: It's usually best to fold this hand to a raise and call out of position. However, if one of the opponents is weak, then sometimes calling can be profitable.

R.advice: It's generally not good to play small suited connectors to a raise out of position unless you feel you have a very good read on your opponent, or your opponent is very weak.

RC.advice: It's usually best to fold a low suited connector like this out of position to a raise and a call. It's rare you'll flop a big draw or top pair often enough. When you do flop top pair, it's very hard to get the hand to showdown out of position.

L.advice: Checking this hand, or sometimes raising and taking the initiative in the hand is the most profitable play long term.
